awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evolution of information processing in the Vibrio fischeri pheromone-signaling network
awd_abstract_narration:
Pheromone signaling controls many important bacterial behaviors, ranging from benign symbiotic relationships between bacteria and their hosts to colonization of human tissues and organs by bacterial pathogens.  The aim of this project is to understand how the local environment (e.g., the environment in the host) affects pheromone signaling and bacterial behaviors such as colonization. This project combines molecular-based microbiology methods with physical and mathematical tools to develop a more complete experimental and theoretical picture of this process. The project will enhance education by training graduate and undergraduate students to perform cross-disciplinary laboratory research. These research experiences will prepare the students for a wide range of careers in the biosciences. The project also includes a formal training experience for secondary science teachers, primarily from high schools with large numbers of students from under-served populations. 

The most important elements of Vibrio fischeri pheromone signaling are the LuxI/LuxR signal-synthase/receptor, which produces and detects a 3OC6 homoserine lactone (HSL) pheromone, and the AinS/AinR synthase/receptor system, which employs a C8 HSL pheromone to drive a different signaling cascade. The complexity of these systems is enhanced by the crosstalk generated by LuxR's recognition of both HSL signals, by the fact that both Lux and Ain are modulated in response to the environment, and by the presence of positive feedback in both the Lux and Ain cascades. The primary goal of this project is to understand how the system gathers and integrates information from its environment. The specific aims are to (i) understand how the pivotal regulator LuxR and its variants integrate information from the two HSL signals, (ii) identify the activation states of the broader pheromone-signaling circuitry and explore how environmental inputs lead to specific outputs, and (iii) test the hypothesis that the architecture of this signaling system allows spatially-heterogeneous environments to trigger population-wide responses over extended distance and time scales. The project will use cytometry and gene reporter methods to characterize LuxR interactions and system states. It will also use microfluidics and microscopy to explore signaling dynamics in heterogeneous environments. The results are expected to yield new insights into how bacteria use environmental cues to control population-level behaviors.

por.por_cntn:
Many bacteria use chemical pheromone signals to communicate between cells.  Such communication requires a minimum population density and is often called “quorum sensing”, implying that the chemical signals function as a way for cells to determine the local density of like cells.  However, while a sufficiently high population density is required for signaling to occur, the signaling pathways are complex, often involving positive feedback loops and multiple chemical signals.  The complexities of these signaling networks and their ability to convey information are not fully understood, but they are known to control group behaviors in bacteria that are important to human health, agriculture, and industry.  Accordingly, it is important to investigate the complexities of bacterial communication and how bacterial pheromone-signaling circuits have evolved to process information.

 

This study used the model bioluminescent marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri to investigate pheromone signaling.  In V. fischeri, multiple chemical signals are produced and ultimately control bioluminescence.  Two distinct pathways, named Ain and Lux, use chemically similar pheromone molecules, and the crosstalk between these systems was a priority for investigation.  The Lux system signal receiver, LuxR, is the archetype for a family of pheromone receptors found in many bacteria, and it has been used widely in the bioengineering of artificial chemical-response circuits.  We discovered that the LuxR signal-receiver has evolved dramatically between different natural isolates of V. fischeri, resulting in major functional differences in crosstalk.  When compared side by side in an otherwise genetically identical background, the corresponding luxR genes underpinned different responses to the two (Ain and Lux) signals.  Moreover, combinations of the signals elicited non-additive responses that differed between LuxR variants.  Interestingly, the genetic differences that have evolved naturally in V. fischeri from different environments parallel changes that have been found in luxR when laboratory-grown cells were enriched for variants that increase or decrease signaling crosstalk.  These results show that V. fischeri strains from different marine hosts and environments have evolved different ways of processing the Ain- and Lux-derived chemical signals, resulting in different outputs depending on the combinations of the two signals present.  We also discovered a new layer of feedback regulation whereby different signals and signal combinations affect levels of the LuxR signal receiver.


This project provided training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, including interdisciplinary exchanges between collaborative groups with expertise in molecular microbiology or biophysics and computational biology.  In addition, K12 teachers were involved and developed new activities for the curricula at their respective home schools.
